properties.name: Dallas, Texas
properties.description: Posted by BforbesThe large urban city is perhaps most famous for what happened here on November 22, 1963 would President John F. Kennedy was shot and killed while driving in the back seat of an open car. The tragedy would spark more conspiracy theories than any other incident in American history, but more importantly, it was the death of one of the most beloved presidents to ever serve.

properties.name: Ford's Theatre, Washington D.C.
properties.description: Posted by BforbesÂ Ford\'s Theatre is the site of Abraham Lincoln\'s assassination by John Wilkes Booth on April 14, 1865. Only five days after General Robert E. Lee surrendered his final Confederate forces, Lincoln would not live to see the reunited country thrive in the decades to follow the brutal war.

properties.name: Independence Hall, Philadelphia
properties.description: Posted by BforbesIndependence Hall is most famous for the meeting place of the Second Congressional Congress that lead to the writing and adoption of the Declaration of Independence on July 4, 1776, our nation\'s birthday.

properties.name: Lexington, Massachusetts
properties.description: Posted by Bforbes1 Moon Hill Rd, Lexington, MA, usaAfter much political friction between the American colonies and the British Parliament over taxes and governmental representation, the Revolutionary War finally saw its violent start in the battles of Lexington and Concord in Massachusetts on April 18. Perhaps the most famous aspect of this historical night and the morning to follow is Paul Revere\'s famous riding through the countryside near Lexington warning the colonists and militia with his shouting of, "The British are coming, the British are coming!" In these first battles of the Revolutionary War, American minutemen would see great success.

properties.name: Pearl Harbor, Hawaii
properties.description: Posted by BforbesPearl Harbor was the target of Japanese aerial attacks on December 7, 1941 that damaged twenty-one ships of the U.S. Pacific fleet and killed 2,350 people in total. These attacks would be the primary motivation for the United States entering the second World War.

properties.name: Plymouth, Massachusetts
properties.description: Posted by BforbesPlymouth Rock is famous for being the site where the Mayflower pilgrims in 1620 first landed on what would become Plymouth Colony and eventually the United States of America.

properties.name: Times Square, New York City
properties.description: Posted by Bforbes1535 Broadway new york, ny 10036Of all the New Year celebrations and celebrities to grace Times Square, perhaps the most famous and enduring memory of this famous place is "The Kiss" photographed by Alfred Eisenstaedt for Life magazine. It depicts the homecoming of World War II soldiers during VJ day, and the immense happiness of the scene cannot go unnoticed. This day would mark a pivotal shift in America\'s place in the world preceding the Cold War.

properties.name: Watergate
properties.description: Posted by Bforbesaddress

properties.name: Watergate Complex, Washington D.C.
properties.description: Posted by BforbesWatergate, Washington D.C.The Watergate complex in Washington D.C. is famous for the arresting of five men under the direction of President Nixon to break into the Democratic National Committee headquarters. It would be the first scandal of several that would fall under the umbrella for the term "Watergate", which would forever change American\'s views of politics and policy.

properties.name: World Trade Center, New York City
properties.description: Posted by BforbesThe attacks on the World Trade Center would mark September 11, 2001 as one of the most horrific days of American history and change American political policy forever. Following the devastating attacks lead by Islamic terrorists that ended nearly three thousand American lives, the Bush administration would launch the War on Terror that would lead to the invasions of Afghanistan and Iraq.

properties.name: Yorktown, Virginia
properties.description: Posted by BforbesYorktown would become known as the location of the last battle of the Revolutionary War that would finally grant America liberty from British rule. After the successful American efforts at Yorktown, King George would lose control of the British Parliament and military action in the colonies would cease.
